definition: to be all talk and no action
only/merely/just/but
grain that has begun to ripen/variant of 衹|只[zhi3]
variant of 只[zhi3]
variant of 只[zhi3]
classifier for birds and certain animals, one of a pair, some utensils, vessels etc
to persuade
to speak/to say/to explain/to scold/to tell off/a theory (typically the last character in a compound, as in 日心說|日心说 heliocentric theory)
variant of 說|说[shuo1]
(negative prefix)/not/no

to do/to make/to produce/to write/to compose/to act as/to engage in/to hold (a party)/to be/to become/to function (in some capacity)/to serve as/to be used for/to form (a bond or relationship)/to pretend/to feign/to act a part/to put on appearance

sentences.english: to say things and never do them is second nature.
Eg: he is always telling, never doing.
A man of words and not of deeds is like a garden full of weeds.
sentences.chinese: 一个只说不做的人就像一个长满野草的花园。

sentences.english: A man of words and not of deeds is like a garden full ofweeds.
sentences.chinese: 只说不做的人，犹如光长野草的花园。

sentences.english: Google makes lots of vague promises, and seems to not deliver.
sentences.chinese: 谷歌作出很多模糊承诺，而且似乎只说不做。

sentences.english: Jack's just another of these hypocrites who are pacifists in word but not in deed.
sentences.chinese: 杰克恰好又是一个只说不做的和平主义者伪君子。

sentences.english: She is a person who talks () but () () . I'm angry with her.
sentences.chinese: 她是个只说不做的人，我很生她的气。

definition: all talk and no action (idiom)/to preach what one does not practice
all talk and no action (idiom)/to preach what one does not practice/same as 光說不做|光说不做[guang1 shuo1 bu4 zuo4]
(idiom) to say one thing and do another
heart and mouth at variance (idiom); keeping one's real intentions to oneself/saying one thing but meaning sth different
to talk big/to sound off/bombastic/grandiloquent
to sing the high part/to speak fine sounding but empty words (idiom)
empty words/bogus speech
superficial show/going through the motions
(lit.) to fire blank shots/(fig.) to be all talk and no action/to shoot one's mouth off/to make empty promises
(idiom) one's actions are in keeping with what one says
lit. say three in the morning but four in the evening (idiom); to change sth that is already settled upon/indecisive/to blow hot and cold
prattle/idle chit-chat

lit. military tactics on paper (idiom)/fig. theoretical discussion that is worse than useless in practice/armchair strategist/idle theorizing/cf Zhao Kuo 趙括|赵括 leading an army of 400,000 to total annihilation at battle of Changping 長平之戰|长平之战 in 260 BC
outside appearance and inner reality differ (idiom); not what it seems/saying one thing but meaning sth different
empty talk/bunk/malicious gossip
impractical dreamer
